items.title: FILE_CHARSET is removed in Django 3.1
items.body:
### Description
In Django 3.1 the `FILE_CHARSET` setting has been [removed](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.1/releases/3.1/#features-removed-in-3-1) in favor of using [UTF-8 encoding for all files](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.0/ref/settings/#file-charset).

This project uses `FILE_CHARSET` twice in [`compilescss.py`](https://github.com/jrief/django-sass-processor/blob/master/sass_processor/management/commands/compilescss.py).

items.title: Auto-compile stops for unknown reason
items.body:
First, this package has been a life saver! Thank you. 

About 6 months ago, auto-compiling when a template is rendered totally stopped for me. I eventually had to completely delete and re-start a new Pipenv virtual environment to get it working. 

Now, the same issue has happened again, there were no package upgrades and errors are never thrown, I only realized it by looking at the CSS being loaded by my browser through my local runserver instance. All works and CSS compiled and updated if I manually run `./manage.py compilescss` but that sort of defeats the purpose. 

I tried trashing my environment and rebuilding, ensure I had the current `libsass` on my machine and `libsass-python`, `django-compressor`, and `django-sass-processor`. I also have deleted all the locally stored static files and started over. 

Has anyone else run into this? 

When loading a template, here are the signals being sent - does django-sass rely on any of them to trigger libsass?

items.title: Add Django 3 support
items.body:
### Description
Django 3.0 was [released today](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.0/releases/3.0/). Support for Django 3.0 should be added to `django-sass-processor`.

The removal of `django.utils.six` seems to be a breaking change. Django suggests to either remove the usage of `django.utils.six` (i.e. only support Python 3.6+) or to use `six` directly.

Only way to get the page to recompile is to restart the server.

items.title: Prevent file exists error when creating SASS_PROCESSOR_ROOT
items.body:
We encountered an issue when running manage.py commands in parallel. Running any manage.py command, e.g. `manage.py check` causes django-sass-processor to create `SASS_PROCESSOR_ROOT`. Unfortunatelly, there is a race condition in the code, see

https://github.com/jrief/django-sass-processor/blob/e54f2c4ae3f8fb7b795060a208ad4f1fd50627fc/sass_processor/finders.py#L25

If the directory does not exist on line 22 but another process creates it, the `os.makedirs()` fails with `FileExistsError: [Errno 17] File exists`

A simple fix is to change the call to `os.makedirs(location,  exist_ok=True)`

items.title: compilescss.Command.parse_template() can't find scss tags in extended DjangoTemplate
items.body:
Hey there - I just poured through the `compilescss.py` module to figure out why I was "Sucessfully compil[ing] 0 referred SASS/SCSS files," and discovered the `walk_nodes()` function cannot see sass_tags unless they are top-level nodes. Moving my `{% sass_src 'scss/stylesheet.scss' %}` from `extended.html` into `base.html` solved it. 

I don't have time to make a pull request just now, but modifying `walk_nodes()` to look a little deeper, or explicitly requiring Django Template users to pay attention to where they put tags will probably fix this.

items.title: Css autocompilation in wrong directory
items.body:
Whenever I runserver and render any template with `sass_src` tag in it, it does actually compile my scss file to css, but in `STATIC_URL` instead of `STATIC_ROOT`.
So on every change of my scss file I have to run `./manage.py compilescss` and then it is compiled next to scss file (which is in `STATIC_ROOT`).
I've read this and it should be done automatically https://github.com/jrief/django-sass-processor/issues/55

items.title: css file preferred over source file while DEBUG=True
items.body:
hey,

I'm not sure if this is intentional or not so I'm describing what just hit me.

If you have used compilescss locally to prepare deployment, sass-processor places a compiled css file right next to the scss source in my case.
Now, if that css file exists, it gets served by runserver no matter if the source changes or not.

I tried to pin this behaviour in the code but couldn't find it, I was suspecting resolve_path should be involved but I can't really tell, sorry.

so, to me this feels like an issue which should be addressed to one of two options:
1. just prefered source file (might lead to other issues in different use cases though)
2. throw a warning in this particular case so it doesn't take long to catch it

let me know what you think and thanks for django-sass-processor in general, helps me a lot.

edit: for now I'm just using the `--delete-files` flag with another `compilescss` call, I guess that's expected to use. hmm, maybe this issue is pointless, still I'd bet I'm not the only one running into this :smile:

items.title: Run post-process at the end of compilescss
items.body:
When using django-sass-processor with [WhiteNoise](http://whitenoise.evans.io/en/stable/) (specifically, the hashed/manifest storage option), the generated CSS files are not hashed, likely because static post-processing doesn't happen.

This is an essential part of far-future caching options.

items.title: SASS_PROCESSOR_ENABLED setting giving a hard time
items.body:
I was trying to use the sass precompilation for a deployable docker image.

Even when running `python manage.py compilescss && python manage.py collectstatic --ignore=*.scss`, I spent hours watching how the app didn't find the compiled css file...

...until I finally took a look at the processor.py file. Turns out it was tripping out because the `.map` was missing, and the `SASS_PROCESSOR_ENABLED` setting wasn't set to `False`.

Although there's a mention of `SASS_PROCESSOR_ENABLED` in the README file, it is not really evident at all you need to set this setting to `False` in order for the `sass_src` helper to work on production environments... Maybe we should add a section about precompiled assets in production environments?

items.title: If any python source file has any syntax error, compilescss fails in a way that hides the source of the problem
items.body:
* during compilescss, every python file in the project is parsed by ast.py just in case it *might* invoke `sass_processor`
* This makes compilescss break if there is any syntax error inside any of those files
* Granted, there probably shouldn't be syntax errors in those files...
* But it's possible to have, for instance, a syntax error in a code path that's never hit in production
* These syntax errors are thus never a problem - until we run compilescss and get a syntax error.

Even worse, the error output that results is so unfathomable that #92 was misdiagnosed as being "a bug in ast.py"; as far as I can tell, it's not a bug in ast.py, it's a syntax error in some other file which would never have been noticed if we weren't asking ast.py to parse the whole file.

https://github.com/jrief/django-sass-processor/blob/c9f546d39f270a4ffa8aefabd93c328f59b891c4/sass_processor/management/commands/compilescss.py#L153

I'm not sure what to do as a permanent fix here; perhaps we can be more selective about which files to parse; or perhaps catch the syntax error and continue?

As a stopgap, I'm going to suggest a patch which would at least be more verbose about which file has the syntax error, to help make it easier to find the source of problems.

items.title: “sass.CompileError: Error: It's not clear which file to import” error when running the `compilescss` command
items.body:
As I've also described in the [StackOverflow question](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/49786406/sass-compileerror-error-its-not-clear-which-file-to-import-arising-when-usi), I have a template that starts like this:

```
{% load compress %}
{% load sass_tags %}

<html>
  <head>
    {% compress css %}
    <link href="{% sass_src 'stylesheets/vendor/materialize_v1.scss' %}" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" />
    <link href="{% sass_src 'stylesheets/terms_of_use.scss' %}" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" />
    {% endcompress %}
```

The `terms_of_use.scss` file imports `materialize_v1`, like so:

```
@import "vendor/materialize_v1";    // Materialize v1.0.0beta
```

However, when I run `python manage.py compilescss`, I get the following error:

```
sass.CompileError: Error: It's not clear which file to import for '@import "vendor/materialize_v1"'.
       Candidates:
         vendor/materialize_v1.scss
         vendor/materialize_v1.css
       Please delete or rename all but one of these files.
        on line 1 of lucy_web/static/stylesheets/terms_of_use.scss
>> @import "vendor/materialize_v1";    // Materialize v1.0.0beta
   ^
```

It seems like it is first compiling `materialize_v1.scss`, after which the `@import` statement becomes ambiguous. Is this indeed what's happening? Should the SASS processor not ideally be 'smart enough' to see that `materialize_v1` is imported in `terms_of_use.scss`, and therefore compile it last?

items.title: APPS_INCLUDE_DIRS will be always empty on Windows
items.body:
Hi, because of this line [L24](https://github.com/jrief/django-sass-processor/blob/43978f8c709d5f195229deb6ec7817a1815a4db6/sass_processor/apps.py#L24) **APPS_INCLUDE_DIRS** will be never filled. 
Because of `os.path.sep` , `base_url`  like `/static/` don't will be striped and `os.path.join` will produce `C:\static\` path.

items.title: absolute paths in css.map file
items.body:
Hi, related to [64](https://github.com/jrief/django-sass-processor/issues/64) but only in parts. 

The problem is that `libsass` generates absolute paths in `css.map` file. I found that on Windows, but probably on *nix too, if `source_map_filename` parameter starts with root `/` slash  like `/static/base.css.map`  as it always the case because of this line: [L74](https://github.com/jrief/django-sass-processor/blob/43978f8c709d5f195229deb6ec7817a1815a4db6/sass_processor/processor.py#L74) `libsass` create absolute paths. If the `source_map_filename` starts without slash like `static/base.css.map` the generated paths would be relative as they should.

items.body:
When attempting to store static files on S3 using the `django-storages` package, I get the following traceback.

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "tutorial_site/manage.py", line 22, in <module>

  File "/opt/virtualenvs/venv/lib/python3.5/site-packages/django/__init__.py", line 27, in setup
```

Alexey

items.title: compilescss does not support jinja2
items.body:
I wanted to add support for the `compilescss` command because currently the command does not support jinja2. There have been a lot of changes in django-compressor's compress command which added support for jinja2 since the compilescss here was written based on that one. I think we/I should refactor the command and inherit from the compress command. This way we can follow the changes there. The current command on django-compressor is very messy, I think it's best to refactor that on their end first and then inherit it here, but add some changes so instead of compressing it would compile SCSS.

It might also be good to add to the readme that setting `SASS_PROCESSOR_ENABLED` is the only way to use Jinja2 with `DEBUG` set to `False`.

items.title: Adding a CONTRIBUTING.md
items.body:
I noticed that in the project single and double quotes are used interchangeably.  (The majority is single quotes it seems.) This together with adding documentation would be beneficial to the project and I think we should start put all of this information in `CONTRIBUTING.md` so we and other can refer to it.

The choice for docstrings is [Numpy](http://sphinxcontrib-napoleon.readthedocs.io/en/latest/example_numpy.html#example-numpy) or [Google](http://sphinxcontrib-napoleon.readthedocs.io/en/latest/example_google.html) style? I've always used the Google one, what do you think?

Then I would just say that the code has to conform with PEP8 but not with the max 80 character rule. Rather I would say conform with a ~90 char rule. I would love to refer you to [this talk](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wf-BqAjZb8M) from Raymond Hettinger about PEP8 that talks about this.

items.title: Incompatibility with django-compressor 2.1
items.body:
_django-compressor_ released a [breaking change](https://github.com/django-compressor/django-compressor/commit/c0010bf2ae4064c11cfee2387f6e06c3880fc6d3#diff-01dc27e1db84256620f15d8a69b327caL119) to their interface from
`compressor.offline.django.DjangoParser.get_nodelist(self, node, original)`
to
`compressor.offline.django.DjangoParser.get_nodelist(self, node, original, context)`

so `sass_processor.management.commands.compilescss.Command.walk_nodes()` is now broken.

I see no easy way to make this change backward compatible with `django-compressor` <= 2.0 _and_ Python 2, as the introspection API to get callable's signature was also changed. I suppose, the best course of actions is to ask `django-compressor` to make this `context` argument have a default value (`None`).

(I'm ended up with hard switching to compressor 2.1, as I no longer need 2.0 compatibility)

The application uses Django REST framework, but not django-crispy-forms (it's an optional dependency). I figured out that django-sass-processor loads all templates to look for `sass_src` tags ([sass_processor/management/commands/compilescss.py#L85](https://github.com/jrief/django-sass-processor/blob/master/sass_processor/management/commands/compilescss.py#L85)). After thinking for a while I thought a template blacklist would be a good solution. What do you think about it?

Thanks,
Frank
